title: Longtime Apple Agency Creative Sues Ad Agency TBWA for Age Discrimination
text:
Duncan Milner, a creative executive who worked on some of the most famous ads for Apple Inc., is suing advertising agency TBWA Worldwide Inc. and various agency executives alleging age discrimination.

The complaint, first reported by Adweek, alleges Mr. Milner’s salary stagnated and his bonus declined after he spent years helping to build TBWA\Media Arts Lab, an Apple-focused group within the larger agency network.

Mr. Milner, 61, was terminated in July, he said in an interview.

The suit puts the spotlight on how Madison Avenue, a business obsessed with youth, treats its older workers.

“We do not believe the legal allegations have merit and intend to defend ourselves vigorously,” a TBWA spokesperson said in an email. TBWA is part of Omnicom Group Inc.

TBWA\Media Arts Lab Chairman Emeritus Lee Clow tapped Mr. Milner as a lead creative on the firm’s Apple business “in or around” 2000, according to the suit. Since then, Mr. Milner helped launch the iPod, iPhone, Apple TV and the iPad, working on high-profile ad campaigns such as “Mac vs. PC.”

The complaint says Mr. Milner worked closely with Steve Jobs, the late chief executive of Apple, and helped grow the Apple account into one with more than $2 billion in billings a year. It is unclear how much Apple currently spends on the business. Billings typically refer to total ad and media spending, and agencies can, in some instances, get a percentage of that.

TBWA in 2017 replaced Mr. Milner on the account with a younger employee, and moved Mr. Milner to MAL\For Good, an agency formed by Laurene Powell Jobs, Steve Jobs’s widow, the lawsuit says. There he managed far fewer employees and earned much less, according to the suit.

Mr. Milner became aware of “the ongoing narrative within the company of the need to hire ‘digital natives,’ i.e., younger people who were familiar with social media,” according to the complaint.

According to the suit, Mr. Milner at one point told Kristen Clark, a chief talent officer for TBWA\Media Arts Lab, “It’s starting to look and smell like age discrimination.”

When Mr. Milner complained to TBWA CEO Troy Ruhanen about his compensation, Mr. Ruhanen cited the economics of the agency, according to the lawsuit.

“I didn’t have any agenda really beyond sort of just being treated fairly, and I just felt that wasn’t the case and felt I didn’t really have another alternative other than to file a suit,” Mr. Milner said in an interview. “I think [age discrimination] is something that is in the industry and isn’t talked about that much.”

“We’ve noticed in cases in the past few years that it’s more and more rare for employees to reach retirement age in this industry,” added Melissa Cardenas, an associate attorney at Shegerian & Associates, the law firm representing Mr. Milner.

TBWA\Media Arts Lab has been lauded for its work on the Apple account, but its relationship with the technology giant has also hit a few bumps over the years.

About six years ago, Apple marketing leader Philip Schiller considered cutting ties with TBWA\Media Arts Lab, according to emails revealed during a trial over an Apple and Samsung Group patent dispute. At the time, rival Samsung had been gaining traction with an ad campaign that made fun of buyers of Apple products.

Write to Alexandra Bruell at alexandra.bruell@wsj.com
description: The complaint, first reported by Adweek, alleges Mr. Milner’s salary stagnated and his bonus declined after he spent years helping to build the highly profitable TBWA\Media Arts Lab, an Apple-focused group within the larger agency network.
